title: 110_hr2236
content: The "Breastfeeding Promotion Act of 2007" may be cited as such. It includes amendments to the Civil Rights Act of 1964, with findings and purposes outlined in Section 101. Congress finds that women with infants and toddlers are a growing segment of the labor force, with over 50% of mothers with children under 1 year old working. The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breastfeeding for at least the first year of a child's life, as research shows that not breastfeeding can lead to various health issues in children. Breastfeeding provides protective effects against chronic diseases for both mothers and children, reducing risks such as diabetes, lymphomas, and postpartum hemorrhage. It also decreases parental absenteeism due to infant illness. Congress recognizes breastfeeding as protected conduct under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act of 1978. The Pregnancy Discrimination Act of 1978 amended title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to protect breastfeeding and expressing breast milk in the workplace. This aims to promote the health of infants and clarify that such actions are covered under the law. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was amended to include lactation as a protected condition, allowing mothers to breastfeed or express milk at work. Employers can now receive a tax credit for providing a suitable environment for breastfeeding or expressing milk on business premises. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was amended to include lactation as a protected condition, allowing mothers to breastfeed or express milk at work. Employers can now receive a tax credit for facilitating employed mothers who breastfeed or express milk for their children. The tax credit for breastfeeding promotion and support allows employers to claim 50% of qualified expenditures, up to $10,000 per year, for equipment to assist employees in breastfeeding or expressing milk at work. The tax credit covers expenses for equipment to assist employees in breastfeeding or expressing milk at work, subject to Health and Human Services standards. It also includes costs for exclusive use property for breastfeeding, with a recapture provision if conditions are not met. The tax credit allows for expenses on equipment to aid in breastfeeding at work, with a recapture provision if conditions are not met. The recapture percentage for the tax credit decreases over the years: 100% in Year 1, 60% in Year 2, 30% in Year 3, and 0% in Year 4 or thereafter. The recapture percentage for the tax credit decreases over the years, starting at 100% in Year 1 and decreasing to 60% in Year 2, 30% in Year 3, and 0% in Year 4 or later. Special rules apply for aggregation of taxpayers and allocation of dollar amounts among them. The text discusses the reduction in basis for property eligible for a tax credit under a specific section. It also states that no other deductions or credits are allowed for expenditures eligible for this credit. Additionally, there are conforming amendments made to Section 38(b) of the tax code to include a new breastfeeding promotion and support credit. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the tax code is amended to include a new item related to a breastfeeding promotion and support credit. The "Safe and Effective Breast Pumps Act" includes a credit for employer expenses to support employed mothers who breastfeed or express milk for their children. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2006. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish performance standards for breast pumps, regardless of their classification under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The standards will be based on efficiency, effectiveness, and sanitation for communal use in workplaces. A compliance policy guide will also be issued to provide complete information for women who want to breastfeed. Women who want to breastfeed will receive comprehensive information about breast pumps. Title IV expands the definition of medical care in the Internal Revenue Code to include breastfeeding equipment and services. Title IV expands the definition of medical care in the Internal Revenue Code to include qualified breastfeeding equipment and services, such as breast pumps and other specially designed equipment to assist mothers in breastfeeding or expressing milk for their child. The amendments made by this section allow for the inclusion of qualified breastfeeding equipment and services in the definition of medical care for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006.
